The Bahrain Government have informed me that Dr. Snow, the State Medical officer, is going to the United Kingdom on four months' leave this summer, from July to October. They enquire whether it would be possible for Dr. Steele to take over the medical duties in the European Ward of the Government Hospital during Dr. Snow’s absence. They would entail a morning and evening round of the ward, and the making up and sending of bills to Messrs. Gray Mackenzie and Company. There are rarely more than 7 or 8 patients at a time in the European Ward. 2. They suggest that Dr. Steele should be paid an allowance of Rs.300/- a month for this work. Dr. Harrison would be called in for surgical cases, and would be paid the usual operation rates. 3. I should be grateful to know whether there is any objection to this arrangement. Sd./- C.J. physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 21; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-12; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence regarding the contract and leave arrangements of Dr Richard Henry Barter Snow, State Medical Officer for the Government of Bahrain. The majority of the correspondence is between Charles Belgrave, Adviser to the Government of Bahrain; the Political Agency in Bahrain; and the Political Residency in Bushire (Bahrain after 1947).
